title: Boris Johnson will call for general election on December 12
text:
Boris Johnson is trying to break the Brexit deadlock (Picture: BBC)

Boris Johnson has said he wants to hold a general election in seven weeks’ time in a bid to break the Brexit deadlock.

The PM said he will give MPs more time to look at his deal – if they agree to a December 12 vote.

It will be the third time in four years that the nation has gone to the polls.

MPs are likely to vote on whether to hold a general election next week and he needs the support of two-thirds of the House of Commons.

The Tories were reportedly split about holding a poll so close to Christmas.

The move in Westminster this afternoon comes amid signs that the EU is set to grant a fresh Brexit delay until the end of January 2020.

Mr Johnson was forced to ask for extra time after the Benn Act made a no-deal Brexit illegal.

The Prime Minister told the BBC: ‘I’m afraid it looks as though our EU friends are going to respond to Parliament’s request by having an extension, which I really don’t want at all.

‘So, the way to get this done, the way to get Brexit done, is, I think, to be reasonable with Parliament and say if they genuinely want more time to study this excellent deal they can have it but they have to agree to a general election on December 12.’

This story is breaking and will be updated.
